natural problem: Suppose a function $f(x)$ has domain $(-\infty,\infty)$ and range $[-11,3]$. If we define a new function $g(x)$ by $$g(x) = f(6x)+1,$$ then what is the range of $g(x)$? Express your answer in interval notation.
natural solution: First, note that $f(x)$ and $f(6x)$ have the same range, because every value assumed by $f(x)$ (at, say, $x=a$) is also assumed by $f(6x)$ (at $x=\frac a6$), and vice versa. Since $g(x)=f(6x)+1$, its range is equal to the range of $f(6x)$ with all values increased by $1$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "range f = {-11..3}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = f (6 * x) + 1"
shows  "range g = {-10..4}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose a function $f(x)$ has domain $(-\infty,\infty)$ and range $[-11,3]$. If we define a new function $g(x)$ by $$g(x) = f(6x)+1,$$ then what is the range of $g(x)$? Express your answer in interval notation. The final Answer is [-10,4]
 ### Proof
 First, note that $f(x)$ and $f(6x)$ have the same range, because every value assumed by $f(x)$ (at, say, $x=a$) is also assumed by $f(6x)$ (at $x=\frac a6$), and vice versa. Since $g(x)=f(6x)+1$, its range is equal to the range of $f(6x)$ with all values increased by $1$.
 Thus, the range of $g(x)$ is $[-11+1,3+1] = \boxed{[-10,4]}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "range f = {-11..3}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = f (6 * x) + 1"
shows  "range g = {-10..4}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Let $f(x)$ be a function with a range of $-11$ to $3$, and let $g(x) = f(6x) + 1$. What is the range of the function $g(x)$? The final answer is from $-10$ to $4$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -11 \<le> f x \<and> f x \<le> 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = f (6 * x) + 1"
shows  "\<forall> x. -10 \<le> g x \<and> g x \<le> 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose a function $f(x)$ has domain $(-\infty,\infty)$ and range $[-11,3]$. If we define a new function $g(x)$ by $$g(x) = f(6x)+1,$$ then what is the range of $g(x)$? Express your answer in interval notation. The final Answer is [-10,4]
 ### Proof
 First, note that $f(x)$ and $f(6x)$ have the same range, because every value assumed by $f(x)$ (at, say, $x=a$) is also assumed by $f(6x)$ (at $x=\frac a6$), and vice versa. Since $g(x)=f(6x)+1$, its range is equal to the range of $f(6x)$ with all values increased by $1$.
 Thus, the range of $g(x)$ is $[-11+1,3+1] = \boxed{[-10,4]}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -11 \<le> f x \<and> f x \<le> 3"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = f (6 * x) + 1"
shows  "\<forall> x. -10 \<le> g x \<and> g x \<le> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that the function $f(x)$ has a value between -11 and 3 inclusive, find the range of the function $g(x) = f(6x) + 1$. The final answer is that $g(x)$ has a value between -10 and 4 inclusive.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f x \<in> extensional UNIV"
and h1 : "\<forall>y. (\<exists>x. f x = y) \<longrightarrow> -11 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. g x = f (6 * x) + 1"
shows  "g_range: \<forall>y. (\<exists>x. g x = y) \<longrightarrow> -10 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 4"
a_4.formal solution:

 Thus, the range of $g(x)$ is $[-11+1,3+1] = \boxed{[-10,4]}$.
 *)

and h2 : "\<forall>x. g x = f (6 * x) + 1"
shows  "g_range: \<forall>y. (\<exists>x. g x = y) \<longrightarrow> -10 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
